review_title: Good company with a solid ethos
pros: As employees, we are recognised for the work that we do.
cons: It is an emotionally demanding place to work because of the nature of what we do. If you're that way inclined, it brings a huge amount of job satisfaction.
Management are unorganized and don't care Poor pay Staff work hard and receive lite recognition No perks or incentives - nothing for Christmas or years of service

pros: Supportive management, hard working dedicated staff, not all but majority of staff
cons: Slow to react, due to restrictions and charity status

review_title: Honestly the worst place I have ever worked.
cons: Everything about that place was vile. Rotten from the top and complete disregard for people that they employ. Loyal to upper management bubble but everyone else is treated appallingly. Lack of training & poor salaries was the icing on the cake.

job_title: Community Support Worker in Birmingham, England
cons: Terrible management and pay, no benefits to the role. Even getting sick pay is nearly impossible.

review_title: Worst employer ever to work for. If you are not senior management, you got no hope in hell to make it.
pros: The only good thing about Reach is, that they have plenty of jobs on offer. Otherwise don't have a good word to say about them
cons: Reach do not value their staff, you could work your hearts content, bring results and make a difference, n they will never show any appreciation. They treat staff like crap, once they used and abused you they will throw you out. For a new employee induction process is horriffic, you get thrown in the deep end n if you survive that and your not seen to comply with how they work, they will make an unfounded accusation and fire you. Its absolutely dishusting an organisation can go around treating people like that an have no come back

pros: Some frontline staff really do care.
cons: Where to start...lack of systems and processes, incredibly low pay in frontline roles, lack of opportunity to feedback to see how the organisation can develop, the CEO is far too operational, poor reputation externally, can’t recruit or retain staff, no performance management data available to actually assess performance, head office building very poor (one of them) basics like hot water and cutlery not available, lack of vision and forward thinking, training miminal, induction poor, worst place I have ever worked!

job_title: Head of Service in Birmingham, England
pros:
Challenging, interesting work in a supportive environment with good colleagues performing a rewarding role in assisting vulnerable members of society.
Very supportive of development opportunities and further training or qualifications.
cons: Not great pay - but on par with other employers in the sector

pros: None, there is no thing good about this service. I was glad to leave
cons: Bad organisation, managers have no experience, do not have any knowledge of service users needs and wages are rubbish. Manages are rude, so much  back biting among staff. People leave really quick

job_title: Residential Care Worker in Ilkeston, England
pros: THe young people I worked with were fantastic and liked spending time talking and interacting with staff.
cons: The management were unhelpful and they treated the care worker like rubbish .They were unprofessional and half the time caused the problems between staff.

pros: helping others charity based good carreer progression
cons: Not enough in the pay structure

pros: None no pros at all NONE
cons: Not allowed to do your job, bullying and harrassment which nothing is done about. Horendous company,higher management,losing quality staff, big staff turnover. Only company i know that staff need to make time up after training .

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Birmingham, England
pros: colleagues are nice to work with
cons: management and salary are not good

job_title: Domestic Abuse Outreach in Nottingham, England
pros: Clients really appricate and value staff
cons: Do not look after staffs well being, stopped sick pay, not clinical supervision. Putting wring people with little experience in to managment so power goes to their head
